Award.AwardTitle: Microbially-Active Functional Material Based Bioreactors for Continuous Production of Biofuels and Industrial Feedstock

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1159772
Chidambaram

The broader scientific impacts of the proposed research involve developing a technology to increase the efficiency in biofuel production. Biologically generated energy and chemical feedstock hold immense potential in using sustainable resources to meet both our energy, as well as industrial needs, while minimizing environmental impacts.

Most industrial processes currently use batch bioreactors due to ease of operation and control. There is an unmet need to develop a cost-effective continuous-flow, immobilized microbial bioreactor that has faster reaction kinetics, high efficiency and productivity. Stable continuous-flow bioreactors that have near constant cell densities do not require frequent inoculation and startup, and allows for consistent production of metabolites of interest, such as bioethanol. The most complex issue to be overcome in the pursuit of this goal, which is also the one issue that was not overcome in previous attempts, is to develop an immobilization material that maintains the viability of the immobilized microbial cells without hindering the metabolic pathways of the microbe. To this extent, the PI has developed a novel US Patent Pending immobilization process to form MAF materials in which both cell viability and metabolic pathways are preserved. MAF materials are thin polymeric fibrous scaffold containing microorganisms within the fibers and are formed via the process of electrospinning. These thin polymeric fibers have high rates of diffusion of nutrients and metabolites to allow microbial survival. Further, the fibers overlap each other in a completely random manner, giving rise to an open pore structure that is ideal for use in a flow reactor. This proposal aims to design, develop, characterize, and evaluate an IMBR in which the MAF material forms the key component. The use of MAF materials in an IMBR will be transformational. The central hypothesis is that such a system will be more efficient and have high productivity.

The principal objectives of the proposed research, in addition to the design and development of MAF materials based laboratory-scale IMBRs, are to: (i) evaluate and compare the efficiencies of the MAF material-based batch fermentors and IMBRs, (ii) determine the longevity and stability of microbes in the IMBRs, and (iii) optimize the MAF material characteristics such as porosity, fiber diameter, and IMBR flow rate, to increase efficiency of IMBRs.

The PI has recently developed the MAF materials via the process of electrospinning; a process that is widely used in the polymeric fiber industry and therefore makes it readily scalable for large-scale commercial use.

Institution.Name: Board of Regents, NSHE, obo University of Nevada, Reno

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Nevada Reno, Chemical and Materials Eng

ProgramElement.Text: Proc Sys, Reac Eng & Mol Therm

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Biologically generated energy and chemical feedstock hold immense potential in using sustainable resources to meet both our energy, as well as industrial needs, while minimizing environmental costs. Most industrial processes currently use batch bioreactors due to ease of operation and control. As a layperson’s example, making beer involves starting yeast cultures in large vats, then waiting for several days, and then removing most of the contents of the vat and restarting the process for next batch. To make 1000 gallons/week, one needs a 1000 gallons vat assuming the batch process takes one week. On the other hand, if the same beer can be made continuously, where raw materials go in one end of the process and the beer comes out of the other end, then one needs only a 6 gallon vat to make 1000 gallons/week as the flow rate of 6 gallons/hour will lead to more than 1000 gallons of beer. Once started the reactor will continuously produce beer. Thus, there will be significant time, capital expenditure and operational cost savings if we transition to a continuous flow reactor. Thus, there is an unmet need to develop a cost-effective continuous-flow, immobilized microbial bioreactor (IMBR) that has faster reaction kinetics, high efficiency and productivity.

 

This project has now successfully demonstrated, on the laboratory scale, several continuous flow reactor designs. These immobilized microbial bioreactors were used both for ethanol production (Figure 1) and for catalytic nanoparticle (Figure 2) production.  In both cases, these IMBRs were found to be better than traditional batch reactors. Overall, the research led to 3 peer reviewed publications, 2 more publications under review and 2 more publication under preparation for submission to journals, it has led to further 4 conference presentations. It also resulted in one invention disclosure.  

 

Broader Impact and Broadening Participation:

The research project originally proposed to involve 1 graduate student, 6 undergraduate students, 2 middle school teachers and 4 middle school students.   

The extreme interest in the project led to more than originally proposed involvement: 2 graduate students (1 PhD, 1 MS), 7 undergraduate students, 2 middle school teachers, and 4 middle school students.

Thus this project was very successful in terms of both technical advancements and societal impact. 

 


Last Modified: 12/31/2017
Modified by: Dev Chidambaram
